lens.lens_summary: June's call reveals a multi-platform, experienced-landlord host who needs every platform microinteraction -- from the trigger that initiates contact, through the hidden rules governing utility caps, calendar blocking, and vetting visibility, to the feedback confirming that her properties and terms are accurately captured -- to match the conversational speed and transparency of a phone call, because she will otherwise default to the platforms she already knows.

discovery.what_this_lens_reveals: June is an experienced real estate agent and three-family-house owner who had never heard of Split Lease despite operating on Furnished Finder and other platforms (june-call.txt, 07:47-08:02: 'I'm surprised I've never heard of [Split Lease] as well as I'm a real estate agent as well. I find everybody my own.'). Discovery happened passively: Split Lease found her listing on Furnished Finder and initiated outreach. Through the Microinteractions lens, the initial outreach is a system-initiated trigger (Saffer, Ch. 2, p. 43-46): the platform detected a matching listing and created the conditions for contact. But the trigger's feedback was insufficient -- June did not even have her email connected to Furnished Finder (june-call.txt, 03:41-03:46: 'you're going to Furnished Finder, is going to my email... I don't think it gave an email'), meaning the system trigger failed to reach her directly. The discovery microinteraction succeeded only because a human (Bryant) called by phone, effectively serving as the manual trigger that the system trigger could not accomplish on its own.

user_state.emotional_state: Mildly surprised but open. She is busy ('I got a couple of zoom calls today,' 00:19) and going through personal difficulties ('I been going through a lot of stuff myself. I'm sorry,' 06:33), but her professional identity as a real estate agent makes her receptive to a new channel.
user_state.knowledge_level: Zero knowledge of Split Lease. Expert-level knowledge of rental platforms generally (Furnished Finder, other unnamed platforms). She knows the landlord domain deeply but has never encountered this specific product.
user_state.commitment_level: Pre-commitment. She did not seek Split Lease out; they found her. She is passively evaluating whether this is worth her limited attention.
user_state.data_available: Her Furnished Finder listing (pricing, photos, property details). No email was shared with Split Lease prior to the call. Phone number was the only contact vector.

reasons: She did not initiate discovery -- she was found. Passive discovery recipients have lower commitment than active seekers.
She is personally overwhelmed ('going through a lot of stuff myself') and time-constrained ('a couple of zoom calls today').
She already has functioning channels (Furnished Finder + other platforms) and finds tenants independently ('I find everybody my own').
The system trigger (Furnished Finder outreach) failed to deliver even basic contact data (email), indicating a fragile discovery pipeline.
dropout_risk.evidence: june-call.txt, 07:47-08:02: 'I'm surprised I've never heard of [Split Lease] as well as I'm a real estate agent as well. I find everybody my own.' Combined with Saffer Ch. 2 p. 25-26: 'make the trigger something the target users will recognize as a trigger in context.' June did not recognize any prior trigger from Split Lease because none existed in her context until Bryant called.

key_quotes.quote: I'm surprised I've never heard of [Split Lease] as well as I'm a real estate agent as well. I find everybody my own.
key_quotes.relevance: Reveals that Split Lease's discovery triggers are not reaching even highly active, multi-platform landlords in the target market. The manual trigger (Bryant's call) succeeded where the system trigger (platform-based outreach) was invisible.

key_quotes.quote: Make the trigger something the target users will recognize as a trigger in context... The more frequently the microinteraction is used, the more visible it should be.
key_quotes.relevance: Discovery is the first and most critical trigger in the host journey. For hosts like June who already operate across multiple platforms, the Split Lease discovery trigger must be visible in the contexts she already inhabits (Furnished Finder, other listing platforms), not buried in an outreach she never received.

key_quotes.quote: Triggers need not be user-initiated. Increasingly, triggers are system-initiated -- when the device or application itself detects that certain conditions have been met and begins a microinteraction.
key_quotes.relevance: Split Lease's outreach to June was a system trigger: the platform detected her listing on Furnished Finder and initiated contact. But system triggers must have clear feedback (Saffer Ch. 4) -- June had no visibility into why or how she was contacted, and the system failed to even capture her email.

evaluation.what_this_lens_reveals: June's evaluation is rapid, transactional, and driven by three hidden rules she applies before engaging: (1) Are there fees to me? (2) Who are these people? (3) Will this interfere with my other platforms? Through the Microinteractions lens, each of these is a rule (Saffer, Ch. 3) that the platform must surface through clear feedback (Saffer, Ch. 4) rather than leaving the host to discover them through interrogation. June asks about fees twice in the transcript (07:32-07:36 and 10:59-11:04), indicating the first answer did not produce sufficient feedback to be retained. She asks to see vetting paperwork (06:04-06:15: 'I need to know who they are and what type of people. I don't want Connie in the house'), demanding visible proof of a rule she cannot verify. She also immediately raises calendar blocking across platforms (05:40-05:52), revealing a hidden operational rule: any commitment to Split Lease has a cost on her other platform availability.

user_state.emotional_state: Cautiously interested but protective. Her tone is business-like with flashes of frustration from past tenant experiences (utility abuse story, 04:26-04:51). She is evaluating risk, not exploring opportunity.
user_state.knowledge_level: She understands landlord economics deeply (rent, deposit, cleaning fee, utility caps) but has zero knowledge of Split Lease's business model, fee structure, or vetting process. She is mapping Split Lease onto her existing mental model of furnished-rental platforms.
user_state.commitment_level: Evaluating with skepticism. Her repeated fee questions and demand for vetting paperwork indicate she is testing whether the rules of this platform align with her existing rules for accepting tenants.
user_state.data_available: Her Furnished Finder listing data (pricing, deposit, cleaning fee). Her personal experience with utility abuse. Her knowledge of her own vetting requirements. No Split Lease-specific data has been received yet.

reasons: She asked about fees twice (07:32 and 10:59), suggesting the first explanation did not produce clear enough feedback to stick. If the platform's fee explanation is equally unclear, she will distrust it.
Her demand for vetting documentation ('I need to know who they are') was redirected to LinkedIn profiles, which may not match her mental model of 'documentation' (credit reports, references, etc.).

Calendar blocking across platforms is an immediate operational cost. If committing to Split Lease requires manual blocking on other platforms without clear tooling, the friction may exceed the benefit.
dropout_risk.evidence: june-call.txt, 06:04-06:15: 'I need to, oh. Or you just going to take care of all that? Cause I need to know who they are and what type of people. I don't want Connie in the house.' Saffer, Ch. 3, Rules, p. 49-52: rules define the hidden parameters of how a microinteraction works. June's evaluation is an attempt to surface the hidden rules of Split Lease before committing.

key_quotes.quote: Are there any fees? Anything? No. There shouldn't be any fees on your company. Does your company have... So there's a service fee, but that's charged to the guests. So no fees on your own.
key_quotes.relevance: June asks about fees and the answer requires two exchanges to land. Saffer's feedback principle (Ch. 4, p. 86: 'Feedback illuminates the rules') applies: the no-fee-to-host rule must be presented with unambiguous feedback at the moment the host needs it, not buried in conversation.

key_quotes.quote: I need to know who they are and what type of people. I don't want Connie in the house.
key_quotes.relevance: The vetting process is a hidden rule. June demands feedback (visible proof) that the rule exists and has been applied. Saffer Ch. 4, p. 86: 'feedback illuminates the rules.' Without visible vetting artifacts, the host cannot verify the rule and must take it on faith.

key_quotes.quote: Tell them it's something they have to decide quickly because I would have to block it on the different platforms I have it on.
key_quotes.relevance: Reveals a cross-platform operational rule: committing to Split Lease requires manual action on other platforms. This is a hidden cost of engagement that the platform must acknowledge and ideally automate. Saffer Ch. 3, p. 64: 'Don't Start from Zero' -- the platform should know she has other listings and account for the cross-platform blocking burden.

key_quotes.quote: Don't Start from Zero.
key_quotes.relevance: June arrives with a fully formed set of rules from her existing platform experience (pricing, deposit, cleaning fee, utility policy). The evaluation microinteraction must start from her existing data, not from zero.

onboarding.what_this_lens_reveals: Onboarding for June is being handled entirely through the phone call -- Bryant promises to email information and create listings on her behalf (09:12, 13:27). The actual platform onboarding is deferred and agent-mediated. Through the Microinteractions lens, this creates a dangerous gap: the human-to-digital handoff is the moment where the trigger changes from a manual trigger June controls (calling/texting Bryant) to system triggers the platform controls (notifications, listing creation confirmation, proposal alerts). Saffer's principle that 'the trigger should initiate the same action every time' (Ch. 2, p. 26) is at risk because June's mental model of the trigger is 'I text Bryant and he handles it.' If the platform introduces different triggers (email notifications, dashboard alerts, login requirements), the consistency is broken. Additionally, June explicitly says she is going through personal difficulties (06:33) and is busy (00:19), making onboarding a depleted-user problem compounded by the need to learn a new set of microinteraction triggers.

user_state.emotional_state: Relieved that Bryant is handling things, but not actively engaged with the platform itself. She is delegating, not onboarding.
user_state.knowledge_level: She has heard of the payment guarantee, the vetting process, and the service-fee-to-guests model. She does not know how the platform works, what it looks like, or what she will be asked to do on it.
user_state.commitment_level: Conditionally committed. She has agreed to receive information and have listings created, but has not committed to using the platform herself. Her commitment is to Bryant, not to Split Lease's digital product.
user_state.data_available: Bryant has her email (obtained during call), her Furnished Finder listing link, and verbal confirmation of pricing/terms. The platform has none of this yet.

reasons: The onboarding is entirely agent-dependent. If Bryant's follow-up email is delayed or unclear, June has no independent path to the platform.
June is personally depleted ('going through a lot of stuff,' 06:33) and time-constrained. Any onboarding friction will be met with abandonment.
Her mental model is 'Bryant does things for me.' Platform self-service onboarding violates this expectation.
She has never seen the platform. The first digital touchpoint is completely unprimed (Saffer Ch. 2 trigger visibility principle).
dropout_risk.evidence: june-call.txt, 13:27: 'I'll get those listings created. I can send you an email with a link to our site and you can expect that shortly after the call.' The onboarding trigger is a link in an email. Saffer Ch. 2, p. 24-25: Antenna Design's MetroCard machines showed that even a simple trigger must be massively visible for unfamiliar users. June's first encounter with the platform will be a link in an email -- the least discoverable form of trigger.

key_quotes.quote: I'll get those listings created. I can send you an email with a link to our site and you can expect that shortly after the call.
key_quotes.relevance: The entire onboarding is promised as a one-way delivery: Bryant creates, June receives. This sets an expectation that the platform is passive for the host. Any subsequent demand for active engagement (account creation, form-filling, verification) will violate the established expectation.

key_quotes.quote: I been going through a lot of stuff myself. I'm sorry.
key_quotes.relevance: Signals a depleted user who will not tolerate complex onboarding. Saffer Ch. 3, p. 67: 'Absorb Complexity' -- the platform must absorb the complexity of onboarding rather than passing it to the host.

key_quotes.quote: Absorb Complexity.
key_quotes.relevance: The platform must absorb the complexity that Bryant currently absorbs manually: creating listings from Furnished Finder data, translating verbal terms into structured fields, pre-populating everything so June's onboarding experience is review-and-confirm, not create-from-scratch.

key_quotes.quote: Have the trigger initiate the same action every time. This is so users can create an accurate mental model of how the microinteraction works.
key_quotes.relevance: June's current trigger is 'text Bryant.' If the platform introduces a different trigger model (login, dashboard, notifications), the inconsistency will erode the mental model Bryant established in the call.

listing_creation.what_this_lens_reveals: June's listing creation is uniquely complex because she has multiple properties (at least 2 apartments in a three-family house in Harlem, june-call.txt 09:36-09:41: 'you can list both of my apartments'), existing listings on Furnished Finder and other platforms, and specific non-standard rules (electric cap at $40, june-call.txt 04:08-04:19). Through the Microinteractions lens, listing creation is a collection of microinteractions that must each handle three challenges Saffer identifies: (1) Don't Start from Zero (Ch. 3, p. 64) -- she already has listings elsewhere, so the platform should import, not rebuild. (2) Limited Options and Smart Defaults (Ch. 3, p. 69) -- her utility cap, cleaning fee, and deposit are established values that should be pre-populated. (3) Preventing Errors (Ch. 3, p. 74) -- the agent promised accurate data entry (09:12: 'I'll make sure that gets accurately entered'), but human transcription from a phone call to a listing is error-prone. Bryant is manually performing the 'rules' layer of a microinteraction that should be systematized. Critically, June expects to review and edit, not to create (09:41-10:12: 'I'll take the information from your other listings, but I'll send it over to you and you can, from there, you'd be able to change anything that didn't look right').

user_state.emotional_state: Expectant and hands-off. She expects Bryant to do the work and send her a finished product to review. She is a reviewer, not a creator.
user_state.knowledge_level: Expert on her own properties. She knows every detail (pricing, deposit, cleaning fee, utility rules, location, transit access). She does not know how Split Lease listings are structured or what fields are required.
user_state.commitment_level: Committed to having listings created (by Bryant), not committed to creating them herself. Her engagement is conditional on the listings being accurate and requiring minimal correction.
user_state.data_available: Furnished Finder listing with photos, description, pricing ($2,690/month), deposit ($2,500), cleaning fee ($140). Verbal utility rule ($40 cap). Two properties. Location near 3/2/9 express downtown. Available March 2nd/3rd.

reasons: If the listing sent to her for review contains errors (pricing wrong, utility rule missing, availability date wrong), her trust in the platform drops immediately.
She has multiple properties and expects both to be listed. If the process handles only one and requires her to repeat for the second, friction doubles.
Her non-standard utility rule ($40 cap, guest pays excess) may not fit standard listing fields, leading to a 'where does this go?' problem.
She expects the listing to pull from her existing Furnished Finder data. If it does not, she perceives the platform as starting from zero -- violating Saffer's Don't Start from Zero principle.
dropout_risk.evidence: june-call.txt, 09:12: 'I'll make sure that that gets accurately entered when the listing is created.' Combined with Saffer Ch. 3, p. 74: 'Preventing Errors.' The accuracy promise is a human rule that should be a system rule: automatic data import from Furnished Finder, structured utility-cap fields, and automated multi-unit duplication.

key_quotes.quote: It's something like join in with, and you can list both of my apartments.
key_quotes.relevance: Multi-unit hosts need batch listing creation. Saffer Ch. 3, p. 69: 'Limited Options and Smart Defaults' -- the second listing should default to the first listing's shared attributes (location, house rules, utility policy) and only require the host to specify what differs (unit size, price, floor).

key_quotes.quote: The electric bill, because people have been ridiculous with the electric bill, I believe it's only covered up to 40, the first $40 I pay and they have to pay different.
key_quotes.relevance: A non-standard utility rule that needs a structured input microinteraction. Saffer Ch. 3, p. 52: 'Designing Rules' -- the platform must have a rule structure that can capture conditional utility arrangements, not just 'utilities included/not included' toggles.

key_quotes.quote: I'll take the information from your other listings, but I'll send it over to you and you can, from there, you'd be able to change anything that didn't look right.
key_quotes.relevance: The host's expected microinteraction is review-and-confirm, not create-from-scratch. This is Saffer's 'Don't Start from Zero' principle (Ch. 3, p. 64) applied to listing creation: pre-populate everything, let the host correct.

key_quotes.quote: Don't Start from Zero.
key_quotes.relevance: June has extensive data on other platforms. The listing creation microinteraction must import this data rather than asking her to re-enter it. Starting from zero is the most common reason multi-platform hosts abandon secondary platforms.

key_quotes.quote: Limited Options and Smart Defaults.
key_quotes.relevance: For multi-unit hosts like June, the second listing should inherit defaults from the first. For all hosts, fields like deposit amount and cleaning fee should suggest market-appropriate defaults that the host can override, not blank fields that demand research.

pricing.what_this_lens_reveals: June's pricing mental model is concrete and established: $2,690/month rent, $2,500 deposit, $140 cleaning fee, $40 utility cap with overage passed to guests (june-call.txt, 03:46-04:19, 08:27-08:32). She does not negotiate these numbers; she states them as fixed rules. Through the Microinteractions lens, each of these is a rule (Saffer Ch. 3) that the platform must capture exactly as stated and confirm through immediate feedback (Saffer Ch. 4). The pricing microinteraction has a critical hidden rule that June reveals: utilities are conditionally split ($40 threshold), which is not a simple on/off toggle but a rule with a parameter. Saffer's principle of 'Absorb Complexity' (Ch. 3, p. 67) applies: the platform must handle the complexity of this conditional rule internally rather than forcing the host into a workaround. Additionally, the cleaning fee and deposit are separate from rent but part of June's mental model of 'what I charge.' The pricing microinteraction must treat these as a unified set, not as separate data-entry steps spread across different screens.

user_state.emotional_state: Confident and protective. She knows her numbers and has been burned by utility abuse. Pricing is not a question for her -- it is a statement of terms.
user_state.knowledge_level: Complete knowledge of her own pricing. She understands per-month rent, deposits, cleaning fees, and utility management from direct experience. She does not know how Split Lease's pricing model works internally (nightly vs. monthly, fee splits, etc.).
user_state.commitment_level: Firm on her numbers. She will not negotiate pricing; she will verify that the platform captures it accurately. Her commitment is contingent on accurate representation.
user_state.data_available: Exact figures: $2,690/month, $2,500 deposit, $140 cleaning fee, $40 utility cap. These are verified against her Furnished Finder listing.

reasons: If the platform's pricing model requires translation from her monthly figure to a different format (nightly rate, 4-week rate), she will distrust numbers she cannot verify.
The conditional utility rule ($40 cap) may not have a standard input field, leading to an error or omission.

She stated her pricing twice in the call (duplicated sections at 03:46/08:27 and 04:05/10:27), suggesting the conversation itself had transcription or repetition issues. If the platform similarly requires repeated input, frustration compounds.
Bryant promised accurate entry (09:12). If the listing shows different numbers, trust is immediately broken.
dropout_risk.evidence: june-call.txt, 04:26-04:51: 'I have had bills of a hundred, $200. I was like, what are you doing in the apartment? It's unbelievable... I had to start protecting myself cause it was getting too much.' The utility cap is not a pricing preference -- it is a learned protection mechanism. Saffer Ch. 3, p. 74: 'Preventing Errors' -- the platform must prevent the error of omitting or misrepresenting this rule, because the host will view it as the platform failing to protect her.

key_quotes.quote: The electric bill, because people have been ridiculous... I have had bills of a hundred, $200. I was like, what are you doing in the apartment?... I had to start protecting myself cause it was getting too much.
key_quotes.relevance: The utility cap is born from a painful experience. It is not a negotiable pricing parameter but a self-protection rule. The pricing microinteraction must treat it as a non-negotiable rule with clear feedback confirming it is active and visible to guests.

key_quotes.quote: One 40 cleaning fee... 2,500 for the deposit... 26 90 for the rent.
key_quotes.relevance: June states all pricing as a unified set: cleaning fee + deposit + rent. The pricing microinteraction should capture and display these as a single pricing summary, not as three separate form steps.

key_quotes.quote: Absorb Complexity.
key_quotes.relevance: The conditional utility split ($40 threshold with guest-paid overage) is a complex rule that the platform must absorb. The host should state the rule once; the platform should encode it, display it on the listing, enforce it during active leases, and calculate overage automatically.

key_quotes.quote: Microcopy.
key_quotes.relevance: The pricing confirmation feedback must use microcopy that mirrors June's language: 'You cover the first $40 of electric. Your guest pays anything above that.' Not platform jargon like 'utility allocation threshold' or 'variable utility surcharge.'

proposal_mgmt.what_this_lens_reveals: June's proposal management requirements are revealed through two key demands: speed of decision and cross-platform coordination. She explicitly states that guests 'have to decide quickly because I would have to block it on the different platforms I have it on' (05:40-05:52). Through the Microinteractions lens, the proposal is a time-sensitive trigger (Saffer Ch. 2): it initiates a sequence of actions that extends beyond the platform (blocking calendars on Furnished Finder, other sites). The rules of the proposal microinteraction (Saffer Ch. 3) must therefore include the cross-platform blocking consequence as a visible part of the flow. June also needs clear feedback (Saffer Ch. 4) at two levels: (1) confirmation that the guest has been vetted to her standards ('I need to know who they are,' 06:04), and (2) confirmation that the terms match what she stated (accurate rent, deposit, cleaning fee, utility rules). The proposal is not just an accept/decline action -- it is a multi-rule verification that the host performs before committing. Saffer's concept of 'Feedback Illuminates the Rules' (Ch. 4, p. 86) is critical: every rule June cares about (vetting, pricing accuracy, calendar impact) must be surfaced as feedback within the proposal view.

user_state.emotional_state: Urgency mixed with caution. She wants fast decisions but also wants thorough verification. These are in tension.
user_state.knowledge_level: She knows what she wants (vetted guests, accurate pricing, fast commitment). She does not know how Split Lease proposals work, what the proposal document looks like, or what she needs to sign.
user_state.commitment_level: Ready to act if conditions are met. She is not browsing; she has a specific pending match (Ariel and Amber). But her action is contingent on verification of terms and guest quality.
user_state.data_available: Guest names (Ariel and Amber), basic guest profiles (mid-thirties, work-related relocation), proposed start date (mid-February, later adjusted to March 2nd/3rd), proposed duration (3 months with extension option). Vetting status was communicated verbally but not documented visually.

reasons: Time pressure creates a narrow window. If the proposal process is slow, she will fill the vacancy through her existing channels.

Cross-platform calendar blocking is a manual burden. If she accepts and then has to manually block on Furnished Finder and other platforms, the operational cost is real and the risk of double-booking exists.
She wants to see vetting documentation but was only offered LinkedIn profiles. If the proposal does not include a vetting summary she trusts, she may reject or delay.
The roommate-matching aspect (Ariel and Amber were matched by Split Lease) adds a hidden rule: June is trusting Split Lease's matching quality, not just the individual guests.
dropout_risk.evidence: june-call.txt, 05:40-05:52: 'Tell them it's something they have to decide quickly because I would have to block it on the different platforms I have it on.' Combined with Saffer Ch. 1, p. 14: 'The Structure of Microinteractions' -- the proposal microinteraction's rules extend beyond the platform itself into cross-platform calendar management, and this extended rule set needs feedback the host can see and act on.

key_quotes.quote: Tell them it's something they have to decide quickly because I would have to block it on the different platforms I have it on.
key_quotes.relevance: The proposal microinteraction has external consequences (cross-platform calendar blocking) that the platform must acknowledge. Saffer Ch. 4, p. 86: feedback must illuminate the rules, including rules that extend beyond the platform.

key_quotes.quote: Everybody has a job. You have like documentation on them.
key_quotes.relevance: June's verification rule: guests must have employment and documentation. The proposal must surface this as visible feedback (Saffer Ch. 4), not as a verbal promise.

key_quotes.quote: We've vetted both Ariel and Amber... payments are guaranteed to you as the landlord... even in the case that a guest missed a payment or didn't pay, you still get paid.
key_quotes.relevance: Two critical rules (vetting + payment guarantee) are communicated verbally. The proposal microinteraction must present these as visible, verifiable feedback artifacts, not text descriptions. Saffer Ch. 4, p. 96: visual feedback is the most effective form.

key_quotes.quote: Feedback Illuminates the Rules.
key_quotes.relevance: Every rule June cares about (vetting status, payment guarantee, pricing accuracy, calendar impact) must be illuminated through feedback in the proposal view. Hidden rules create the same risk as the iPhone silent-mode alarm: the host does not know what they do not know.

active_lease.what_this_lens_reveals: June's active lease concerns are dominated by a single, experience-driven fear: utility abuse. Her most emotionally charged moment in the call is the utility story (04:26-04:51: 'I have had bills of a hundred, $200... heat is on while the windows are open. They're not home, running, you know, all of that stuff'). Through the Microinteractions lens, the utility cap is a loop (Saffer Ch. 5, p. 109-121): a recurring microinteraction that repeats each billing cycle. The loop has a rule (first $40 covered by host, overage by guest), feedback requirements (monthly utility reporting visible to both parties), and a potential mode shift (if the guest consistently exceeds the cap, what happens?). Saffer's concept of 'Long Loops' (Ch. 5, p. 117) applies: over the course of a 3+ month lease, the utility monitoring microinteraction needs to evolve -- perhaps becoming less prominent if the guest stays within bounds, or escalating alerts if they consistently exceed the cap. June also mentions a roommate replacement scenario (12:29-12:40: 'they basically found a new roommate and they just stayed'), indicating that the active lease phase includes guest turnover events that need their own microinteraction structure (triggers for replacement notification, rules for lease modification, feedback confirming continuity).

user_state.emotional_state: Vigilant and protective. Her past utility abuse has created a monitoring mindset. She will be watching utility-related feedback closely during the active lease.
user_state.knowledge_level: Expert on active-lease management from her multi-property experience. She knows what goes wrong (utility abuse, tenant quality issues) and has developed rules to protect herself ($40 cap). She does not know how Split Lease monitors or enforces these rules during the lease.
user_state.commitment_level: Committed to the lease terms she set, but will disengage if those terms are not enforced. Her continued engagement depends on the platform demonstrating it protects her interests.
user_state.data_available: Utility bills (she tracks them), tenant behavior patterns, lease terms. The platform should have lease start/end dates, payment records, and the utility cap rule.

reasons: If the utility cap is not enforced automatically, June must monitor and enforce it herself, adding friction to the active lease experience.
Roommate replacement events (which she has experienced before) require a microinteraction that does not currently seem to exist on the platform.
If payment guarantee is not visibly confirmed each cycle, the verbal promise degrades over time (Saffer Ch. 5, Long Loops: the microinteraction must remain credible over extended use).
She manages multiple properties and platforms. If the active lease management on Split Lease is more burdensome than on her other platforms, she will deprioritize it.
dropout_risk.evidence: june-call.txt, 04:26-04:51: 'I have had bills of a hundred, $200... I had to start protecting myself cause it was getting too much.' Saffer Ch. 5, p. 117: 'Long Loops' -- the utility monitoring microinteraction must be designed for sustained repetition over the full lease term, adapting its feedback based on the guest's behavior pattern.

key_quotes.quote: I have had bills of a hundred, $200. I was like, what are you doing in the apartment? It's unbelievable. I have a three family house... the heat is on while the windows are open. They're not home, running, you know, all of that stuff. So I had to start protecting myself cause it was getting too much.
key_quotes.relevance: The most emotionally charged moment in the call. The active lease utility loop must provide continuous, ambient feedback (Saffer Ch. 4, p. 96: visual feedback) showing utility tracking relative to the $40 cap, so June does not have to monitor it manually.

key_quotes.quote: No tenants. They basically found a new roommate and they just stayed and they just kept looking.
key_quotes.relevance: Roommate replacement is an active-lease event that needs its own microinteraction: a trigger (replacement notification), rules (lease continuity, new vetting), and feedback (confirmation of the new arrangement). Saffer Ch. 5, Modes, p. 111: this may be a mode shift within the active lease -- from 'stable occupancy' mode to 'replacement' mode.

key_quotes.quote: Long Loops.
key_quotes.relevance: Active leases are long loops by definition. The utility monitoring, payment confirmation, and guest behavior microinteractions must be designed for sustained repetition across months, with the feedback adapting based on accumulated data (e.g., if the guest has stayed under the utility cap for 3 months, the monitoring can become more ambient; if they exceed it, alerts should escalate).

key_quotes.quote: Modes... Spring-Loaded and One-off Modes.
key_quotes.relevance: The active lease has at least two modes: stable occupancy and roommate replacement. The replacement mode is spring-loaded: it activates when a guest departs and reverts when a replacement is confirmed. The platform must handle this mode transition with clear triggers and feedback.

retention.what_this_lens_reveals: June shows strong retention signals despite being a first-time Split Lease user. She proactively offers to list both apartments (09:36-09:41), asks about the possibility of longer stays (04:59: 'they just want three months or that's just the start?'), and is receptive to Bryant finding guests for her other property (12:40-13:17). Through the Microinteractions lens, retention is about the long loop (Saffer Ch. 5, p. 117): how does the microinteraction change after the first cycle? June's willingness to expand her engagement is a signal that the platform's long loop should evolve from single-property/single-lease to multi-property/multi-lease management. The retention microinteraction should also address the extension scenario: guests who start with 3 months and extend (05:09-05:40: 'start with three months... and then there's the option to extend'). Saffer's principle that microinteractions should 'not start from zero' (Ch. 3, p. 64) is critical for retention: the second listing, the second lease, the extension of an existing lease should all build on what the platform already knows, not restart the process.

user_state.emotional_state: Cautiously optimistic. She sees potential value in the platform (someone else finds guests for her) but has not yet experienced a completed cycle to validate the promise.
user_state.knowledge_level: She understands the basic proposition (guaranteed income, vetted guests, agent support). She does not know what the long-term platform experience will be like -- whether renewals are easy, whether multi-property management is supported, whether her agent remains the same.
user_state.commitment_level: Exploratory expansion. She is willing to list more properties and accept longer stays, but her retention depends on the first lease going well.
user_state.data_available: Two properties to list. History on other platforms (Furnished Finder, others). Existing tenant relationships and turnover patterns. The platform should accumulate data from the first lease (payment reliability, utility compliance, guest behavior) to inform retention offers.

reasons: She proactively offered to expand (list second apartment), which is a strong retention signal.
Bryant offered ongoing sourcing for her other property, creating a service relationship beyond the first transaction.
However, retention depends entirely on the first lease going well. If the first experience has friction (pricing errors, utility disputes, slow communication), the expansion signal will reverse.
dropout_risk.evidence: june-call.txt, 09:36-09:41: 'It's something like join in with, and you can list both of my apartments.' And 12:40-13:17: Bryant offers to find guests for the other property, and June says 'Okay, great.' Saffer Ch. 5, p. 117: long loops should evolve the microinteraction over time, making repeated engagement progressively easier and more valuable.

key_quotes.quote: It's something like join in with, and you can list both of my apartments.
key_quotes.relevance: Proactive expansion signal. The retention microinteraction should have a trigger that surfaces the second-listing opportunity at the right moment (after the first listing is confirmed, not before). Saffer Ch. 2: trigger timing matters -- the multi-property listing trigger should appear when the host is in a positive state after first-listing confirmation.

key_quotes.quote: They had mentioned basically looking to start with three months... there's the option to extend if it would work for you.
key_quotes.relevance: Lease extension is a retention microinteraction. It needs a clear trigger (approaching lease end), clear rules (how extension terms are set), and clear feedback (what happens to pricing, availability, and calendar blocking on other platforms). Saffer Ch. 5, long loops.

key_quotes.quote: Your place is actually a really great location... I'd be happy to let you know of any interest in the other place too.
key_quotes.relevance: The agent is manually creating the retention loop. The platform should systematize this: when a host has multiple properties, the platform should surface demand signals for unlisted properties as a retention microinteraction.

key_quotes.quote: Long Loops.
key_quotes.relevance: Retention is the ultimate long loop. The microinteraction of listing, leasing, and re-listing should get smoother each cycle. Saffer: 'What happens over time with the microinteraction?' For retention, each cycle should require less input and provide more value based on accumulated history.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Hidden Rules Demand Visible Feedback: June carries non-standard rules (utility cap, vetting requirements, cross-platform calendar blocking) that are invisible to the platform unless explicitly surfaced. Each of these hidden rules creates dropout risk when the platform fails to capture, confirm, or enforce them.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: june-call.txt, 04:08-04:51 (utility cap rule), 06:04-06:15 (vetting documentation rule), 05:40-05:52 (cross-platform blocking rule). Saffer Ch. 3, p. 49-52: 'Rules define the hidden parameters of how a microinteraction works.' Saffer Ch. 4, p. 86: 'Feedback Illuminates the Rules.' Every hidden rule June carries must be captured as a platform rule and confirmed through visible feedback.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Don't Start from Zero: June has extensive existing data across platforms (Furnished Finder listings, established pricing, existing tenant history, multiple properties). Every phase that asks her to re-enter known information violates Saffer's principle and increases abandonment risk for a host who already has functioning alternatives.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: june-call.txt, 03:46 (pricing already on Furnished Finder), 09:41 (Bryant pulls from her existing listing), 09:36 (second property should inherit from first). Saffer Ch. 3, p. 64: 'Don't Start from Zero.' The existing library element works-006 addresses mental-model translation but not data import from competing platforms. This lens adds the multi-platform data portability dimension.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Agent-as-Manual-Trigger: Bryant serves as June's primary trigger for every microinteraction. Discovery, evaluation, onboarding, listing creation, and proposal management all flow through Bryant. The platform itself has no independent trigger relationship with June. If Bryant is unavailable, every microinteraction stalls.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: june-call.txt, 13:27 (Bryant creates listings), 06:37 (Bryant sends email), 12:40-13:17 (Bryant sources for second property). Saffer Ch. 2, p. 23-26: manual triggers must be something the user recognizes as a trigger in context. June's recognized trigger is Bryant. The platform must inherit this trigger relationship, not compete with it.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Multi-Property Host Requires Batch Operations and Inherited Defaults: June owns a three-family house with at least two listable units. Every phase that handles a single property must also work at scale for multi-property hosts, or the operational cost multiplies and the host reverts to simpler platforms.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: june-call.txt, 09:36-09:41 ('list both of my apartments'), 04:08-04:19 (utility rule applies to the whole house), 12:29-12:40 (tenant turnover across units). Saffer Ch. 3, p. 69: 'Limited Options and Smart Defaults' -- the second unit should inherit the first unit's defaults. The existing library element behaves-007 addresses multi-unit batch operations but does not address the cross-platform import dimension that June's case introduces.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Protection-Driven Rules from Past Negative Experiences: June's requirements are not preferences -- they are learned protections from painful experiences (utility abuse, bad tenants). The platform must treat these not as optional settings but as non-negotiable rules with enforcement mechanisms.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: june-call.txt, 04:26-04:51 ('I had to start protecting myself cause it was getting too much'), 06:04-06:15 ('I don't want Connie in the house'). Saffer Ch. 3, p. 52: 'Designing Rules' -- rules should protect the user from errors and bad outcomes. June's self-imposed rules are exactly this: she has designed her own microinteraction rules (utility cap, vetting demand) to protect herself from recurring negative experiences. The platform must encode and enforce these, not treat them as data entry.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Feedback Must Survive Repetition: June asks about fees twice (07:32 and 10:59), indicating that verbal feedback does not persist. Every critical rule (no fees to host, payment guarantee, vetting status) must be delivered as persistent, visible, reviewable feedback -- not one-time verbal or text explanations.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: june-call.txt, 07:32-07:36 and 10:59-11:04 (identical fee question asked twice). Saffer Ch. 4, p. 86-92: 'Feedback Illuminates the Rules' and 'Feedback Is for Humans.' Feedback that does not persist is feedback that has failed. The platform must provide persistent visual indicators for every critical rule, not rely on one-time explanation.

journey-types.json -- Host journey phase definitions (discovery through retention). Used to ensure all 8 phases are addressed and phase descriptions align with platform terminology.

library/elements.json (first 400 lines) -- Existing element library with 357 elements. Reviewed for coverage gaps. Key observations: heavy coverage of Kahneman System 1/2 lens from Andreas call; strong coverage of onboarding-listing_creation-pricing-proposal_mgmt phases; weaker coverage of discovery and retention phases; no elements yet address cross-platform data import, conditional utility rules, or multi-platform calendar synchronization. This lens adds: the Microinteractions structural model (triggers, rules, feedback, loops/modes) as a new analytical framework; the multi-platform experienced host as a new user archetype; and protection-driven rules as a new pattern category.
